soundfanatic 161052326475 "2017-05-25 09:09:38 GMT" https://soundfanatic.tumblr.com/post/161052326475/forget-the-myths-what-adhd-is-actually-like "neurodiversitysci:                  This started life as a more accessible version of my ADHD list for writers
column2: and turned into a two-part series. Thatâ€™s how ADHD works sometimes.This is part 1.EDIT 1/1/17: New images added to point #7 and header formatting fixed. Please share this version instead!1. Weâ€™re not all hyperactive
column3: extraverted little boys.We can be:AdultsFemaleNot hyperactive (this is called Inattentive type).Â IntrovertsAnother myth is that men have hyperactive or combined ADHD and women have inattentive ADHD. But there are men with inattentive ADHD and women with hyperactive or combined ADHD. Theyâ€™re just less common.Yet another myth is that people with ADHD lose their hyperactive symptoms by the time they grow up. Many do
column4: but there are still adults with combined type around.2. Some of us get good grades and behave well in school.A common myth about ADHD is that weâ€™re just misbehaving kids who need to be spanked more. Nonsense like this:But actually
column5: many of us looked more like this in school
column6: especially if we had Inattentive type ADHD.When bored
column9: or doodle. Teachers might not notice us
column10: or might even enjoy teaching us.  Furthermore
column11: some people with ADHD are smart
column13: and are interested in school. This lets them get good gradesâ€¦until the demands to turn organized work in on time become too overwhelming.3. We can pay attention. We just canâ€™t regulateÂ our attention.Some parents and doctors claim a child canâ€™t have ADHD if they can focus on video games for hours. Nothing can be further from the truth. If anything
column14: we have trouble stopping!We can focus for hours on something that interests us. Or on procrastinating. But weâ€™re worse than most people at focusing on things that are boring or unimportant to us. We also have difficulty controlling the amount of attention we pay. Our attention works like this:When we pay full-on attention
column15: itâ€™s calledÂ â€œhyperfocus.â€Hyperfocus is great when youâ€™re writing a paper
column16: but exhausting when youâ€™re doing mindless tasks like washing dishes or checking e-mail.4. We donâ€™t always think fast
column18: or have lots of energy.                 Some of us struggle with fatigue and slow processing speed. In fact
column21: was proposed to describe this problem.The stereotype about ADHD is that we canâ€™t focus because there are too many thoughts and sensations in our heads
column22: and we keep jumping from one to another. But those of us who fit the Sluggish Cognitive Tempo description can be distracted for very different reasons.Imagine how you feel after getting only three hours of sleep several nights in a row. You probably feel groggy
column23: have very few thoughts moving through your head
column24: and respond slowly when people talk to you. You probably have trouble concentrating
column27: and making decisions. Instead of having too many thoughts
column29: you have too few. You just feel like you donâ€™t have the energy to pay attention to anything. Thatâ€™s what itâ€™s like.This experience is sometimes calledÂ â€œbrain fog.â€We can also have inconsistent processing speed. Sometimes
column30: I think and talk so fast it irritates other people. Everything feels like itâ€™s happening in slow motion and I get bored. I interrupt other people because Iâ€™ve already processed what theyâ€™re saying before they finish
column31: and I donâ€™t realize itâ€™s my listening thatâ€™s finished
column33: I am just about to answer someoneâ€™s question when they irritably repeat themselves
column34: or ask why Iâ€™m taking so long to answer. It feels like Iâ€™m thinking at normal speed
column35: but other peopleâ€™s reactions make clear that Iâ€™m going too slow. 5. Weâ€™re not all athletic adrenaline junkies.Thereâ€™s a stereotype that weâ€™re adrenaline junkies who perform surgeries
column37: or travel round the world starting new businesses.   First of all
column38: many of us have delays or disabilities with motor coordination. As children
column39: people with ADHD can have difficulty with:Using scissorsHandwritingTying shoesThrowing or catching a ballRiding a bikeSecond
column40: when you look at the people with ADHD who fit this stereotype
column41: what do they have in common? Most are men
column42: with high energy and either hyperactive/impulsive or combined type ADHD.Even in mice
column43: male and female brains react to stress differently. Itâ€™s possible that men
column45: are more likely to thrive on stress. By contrast
column47: and might get overwhelmed instead.Up to a certain point
column48: increasing stress helps you focus. Thatâ€™s why some people wait until the last minute to study for exams.But past a certain amount
column49: becoming more stressed starts to hurt you.And long term
column50: living under high stress hurts both your physical and mental health.Some people with ADHD rely on increasing their stress levels to get stuff done. A disability services counselor I met in graduate school actually recommended this strategy to me.Â She should have known better. Even if you benefit from putting yourself under stress
column51: you will pay steep long-term costs. Having seen family and friends pay them
column52: I donâ€™t think the costs are worth it. TL;DR
column53: Not all of us benefit from stress
column54: so we donâ€™t all seek it out.6. Some of us are socially awkward penguins
column55: not social butterflies.Another stereotype describes us as social butterflies who hide our school difficulties by playing class clown or making friends with everyone. But some of us are socially awkward.We can come off as awkward or rude because weâ€™re not paying attention and miss cues.We can have poor sense of timing and inconsistent processing speed. These can make us interrupt other people
column56: or just seem weird.We can be annoying. We interrupt other people
column59: or zone out in the middle of a conversation.Like elderly people
column60: we can tell you the same thing many times because we forgot we told you.We also often forget what you tell us. It takes heroic effort to remember
column63: many of us have mild social difficulties that donâ€™t meet criteria for Autism Spectrum Disorder.  People with ADHD are also more likely to be on the autism spectrum.Â 7. Being diagnosed and labeled can improve our lives.People worry about letting their child be diagnosed or labeled
column64: because they think it will make people treat their child worse.But when you actually talk to people with ADHD
column65: many of them had a very different experience.Having the label is a relief.It gives you understanding. It gives you words to describe your experiences for the first time. It means youâ€™re not broken. It means there are other people like you.The title of a popular ADHD book
column68: or crazy?â€ describes the feeling well.                 Iâ€™ve written about how bad it is to grow up without a diagnosis
column69: and how good it feels to get one
column72: and here.What it feels like before diagnosis:What it feels like after diagnosis:8. Stimulants donâ€™t turn you into a zombie
column74: either.If a person with ADHD gets the right medication at the right dose
column75: they donâ€™t turn into zombies. They just become a better-functioning version of themselves.But stimulants donâ€™t cure ADHD. Yes
column76: if taken for a long time
column77: they do create changes in the brain. But the person still has the same underlying characteristics. If they stop taking stimulants
column78: their ADHD symptoms will become visible again.Stimulants
column80: should be thought of like insulin for diabetics. Theyâ€™re not a cure
column81: and they need to be taken long-term. But they help you manage your symptoms and live a full life.9. Stimulants arenâ€™t the only way to manage ADHD
column82: and some of us choose not to take them.Some people with ADHD choose not to take stimulants. And itâ€™s not just because they hate drug companies or fear that the drugs will turn them into a different person.First of all
column83: only 80% of people with ADHD respond to stimulants. The other fifth can try other kinds of medications. These include:wakefulness medications (like Provigil)
column84: medications that treat mood disorders (like Welbutrin)
column86: Edit:Â NOT Concerta)Non-stimulants are less powerful than stimulants
column87: so they reduce ADHD symptoms less
column88: but they also have fewer side effects.Which brings me to the main reason people with ADHD avoid stimulants: side effects.Stimulants activate the sympathetic nervous systemâ€”the one involved in the fight or flight response. As a result
column89: you can get the following side effects:Increased heart rateIncreased anxietyLoss of appetiteIncreased rate of headaches and migrainesWeight lossNote: These symptoms are probably the reason for the claim that stimulants stunt childrenâ€™s growth.If weâ€™re not taking stimulants
column90: you might see us consuming huge quantities of more socially acceptable drugs: caffeine and nicotine.That person who goes through a pot of coffee a day
column91: always has a Pepsi in hand
column92: or canâ€™t quit smoking? They might be self-medicating their ADHD.Please share this information and help combat myths about ADHD." False text
